originContent: # BPCells
translatedContent: # BPCells

originContent: BPCells is a package for high performance single cell analysis of large RNA-seq and ATAC-seq datasets.
translatedContent: BPCells is a package for high performance single cell analysis of large RNA-seq and ATAC-seq datasets.

originContent: It can run normalization and PCA of a 1.3M cell dataset in 4 minutes with 2GB of RAM, or create scATAC-seq peak matrices from fragment coordinates with 50x less CPU time than ArchR or SnapATAC2.
translatedContent: It can run normalization and PCA of a 1.3M cell dataset in 4 minutes with 2GB of RAM, or create scATAC-seq peak matrices from fragment coordinates with 50x less CPU time than ArchR or SnapATAC2.

originContent: BPCells can even handle the full CELLxGENE census human dataset, running full precision PCA on a 44M cell x 60k gene matrix in 6 hours on a laptop or <1 hour on a server. See our [benchmarks page](https://bnprks.github.io/BPCells/articles/web-only/benchmarks.html) for details.
translatedContent: BPCells can even handle the full CELLxGENE census human dataset, running full precision PCA on a 44M cell x 60k gene matrix in 6 hours on a laptop or <1 hour on a server. See our [benchmarks page](https://bnprks.github.io/BPCells/articles/web-only/benchmarks.html) for details.

originContent: BPCells provides:
translatedContent: BPCells provides:

originContent: - Efficient storage of single cell datasets via bitpacking compression
translatedContent: - Efficient storage of single cell datasets via bitpacking compression

originContent: - Fast, disk-backed RNA-seq and ATAC-seq data processing powered by C++
translatedContent: - Fast, disk-backed RNA-seq and ATAC-seq data processing powered by C++

originContent: - Downstream analysis such as marker genes, and clustering
translatedContent: - Downstream analysis such as marker genes, and clustering

originContent: - Interoperability with AnnData, 10x datasets, R sparse matrices, and GRanges
translatedContent: - Interoperability with AnnData, 10x datasets, R sparse matrices, and GRanges

originContent: - Demonstrated scalability to 44M cells on a laptop
translatedContent: - Demonstrated scalability to 44M cells on a laptop

originContent: Additionally, BPCells exposes its optimized data processing infrastructure for use in scaling 3rd party single cell tools (e.g. Seurat)
translatedContent: Additionally, BPCells exposes its optimized data processing infrastructure for use in scaling 3rd party single cell tools (e.g. Seurat)

originContent: ## [Learn more at our website](https://bnprks.github.io/BPCells/)
translatedContent: ## [Learn more at our website](https://bnprks.github.io/BPCells/)

originContent: ## R Installation
translatedContent: ## R Installation

originContent: We recommend installing BPCells directly from github:
translatedContent: We recommend installing BPCells directly from github:

originContent: remotes::install_github("bnprks/BPCells/r")
translatedContent: remotes::install_github("bnprks/BPCells/r")

originContent: Before installing, you must have the HDF5 library installed and accessible on your system.
translatedContent: Before installing, you must have the HDF5 library installed and accessible on your system.

originContent: HDF5 can be installed from your choice of package manager. See operating system specific instructions below.
translatedContent: HDF5 can be installed from your choice of package manager. See operating system specific instructions below.

originContent: For Mac and Windows users having trouble installing from github, check our [R-universe](https://bnprks.r-universe.dev/BPCells)
translatedContent: For Mac and Windows users having trouble installing from github, check our [R-universe](https://bnprks.r-universe.dev/BPCells)

originContent: page for instructions to install pre-built binary packages. These binary packages automatically track the latest github main branch.
translatedContent: page for instructions to install pre-built binary packages. These binary packages automatically track the latest github main branch.

originContent: BPCells is available via conda thanks to [@mfansler](https://github.com/mfansler) from the Conda Forge R team (see [issue #241](https://github.com/bnprks/BPCells/issues/241) for details).
translatedContent: BPCells is available via conda thanks to [@mfansler](https://github.com/mfansler) from the Conda Forge R team (see [issue #241](https://github.com/bnprks/BPCells/issues/241) for details).

originContent: Any issues with the bioconda package should be reported at [bioconda-recipes](https://github.com/bioconda/bioconda-recipes/). Version updates are managed by the bioconda team.
translatedContent: Any issues with the bioconda package should be reported at [bioconda-recipes](https://github.com/bioconda/bioconda-recipes/). Version updates are managed by the bioconda team.

translatedContent: <details>

translatedContent: <summary>Click here for operating system specific installation information for github-based installs</summary>

originContent: ### Linux
translatedContent: ### Linux

originContent: Obtaining the HDF5 dependency is usually pretty straightforward on Linux
translatedContent: Obtaining the HDF5 dependency is usually pretty straightforward on Linux

originContent: - apt: `sudo apt-get install libhdf5-dev`
translatedContent: - apt: `sudo apt-get install libhdf5-dev`

originContent: - yum: `sudo yum install hdf5-devel`
translatedContent: - yum: `sudo yum install hdf5-devel`

originContent: - conda: `conda install -c conda-forge hdf5`
translatedContent: - conda: `conda install -c conda-forge hdf5`

originContent: - Note: Linux users should prefer their distro's package manager (e.g. `apt` or `yum`) when possible,
translatedContent: - Note: Linux users should prefer their distro's package manager (e.g. `apt` or `yum`) when possible,

originContent: as it appears to give a slightly more reliable installation experience.
translatedContent: as it appears to give a slightly more reliable installation experience.

originContent: ### Windows
translatedContent: ### Windows

originContent: Compiling R packages from source on Windows requires installing [R tools for Windows](https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/Rtools/). See [Issue #9](https://github.com/bnprks/BPCells/issues/9) for more discussion.
translatedContent: Compiling R packages from source on Windows requires installing [R tools for Windows](https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/Rtools/). See [Issue #9](https://github.com/bnprks/BPCells/issues/9) for more discussion.

originContent: ### MacOS
translatedContent: ### MacOS

originContent: For MacOS, installing HDF5 through homebrew seems to be most reliable: `brew install hdf5`.
translatedContent: For MacOS, installing HDF5 through homebrew seems to be most reliable: `brew install hdf5`.

originContent: **Mac-specific troubleshooting**:
translatedContent: **Mac-specific troubleshooting**:

originContent: - **Macs with ARM CPUs**: a common error is to have an ARM-based HDF5 install but an x86-based
translatedContent: - **Macs with ARM CPUs**: a common error is to have an ARM-based HDF5 install but an x86-based

originContent: R install. This will cause errors when BPCells tries to access HDF5 during installation.
translatedContent: R install. This will cause errors when BPCells tries to access HDF5 during installation.

originContent: - Check your R installation
translatedContent: - Check your R installation

originContent: by running `sessionInfo()`, and seeing if it lists ARM or x86 under "Platform".
translatedContent: by running `sessionInfo()`, and seeing if it lists ARM or x86 under "Platform".

originContent: - The easiest option is to use
translatedContent: - The easiest option is to use

originContent: ARM R because homebrew will default to an ARM hdf5 installation
translatedContent: ARM R because homebrew will default to an ARM hdf5 installation

originContent: - It is [possible](https://codetinkering.com/switch-homebrew-arm-x86/) (though tricky) to install an x86 copy of homebrew in order to access an x86 version of hdf5
translatedContent: - It is [possible](https://codetinkering.com/switch-homebrew-arm-x86/) (though tricky) to install an x86 copy of homebrew in order to access an x86 version of hdf5

originContent: - **Older Macs (10.14 Mojave or older)**: The default compiler on old Macs does not support needed
translatedContent: - **Older Macs (10.14 Mojave or older)**: The default compiler on old Macs does not support needed

originContent: C++17 filesystem features. See [issue #3](https://github.com/bnprks/BPCells/issues/3#issuecomment-1375238635) for
translatedContent: C++17 filesystem features. See [issue #3](https://github.com/bnprks/BPCells/issues/3#issuecomment-1375238635) for

originContent: tips getting a newer compiler set up via homebrew.
translatedContent: tips getting a newer compiler set up via homebrew.

originContent: ### Supported compilers
translatedContent: ### Supported compilers

originContent: In most cases, you will already have an appropriate compiler. BPCells recommends
translatedContent: In most cases, you will already have an appropriate compiler. BPCells recommends

originContent: gcc >=9.1, or clang >= 9.0.
translatedContent: gcc >=9.1, or clang >= 9.0.

originContent: This corresponds to versions from late-2018 and newer.
translatedContent: This corresponds to versions from late-2018 and newer.

originContent: Older versions may work in some cases so long as they
translatedContent: Older versions may work in some cases so long as they

originContent: have basic C++17 support, but they are not officially supported.
translatedContent: have basic C++17 support, but they are not officially supported.

originContent: </details>
translatedContent: </details>

translatedContent: <details>

translatedContent: <summary>Click here for troubleshooting information for github-based installs</summary>

originContent: ### General Installation troubleshooting
translatedContent: ### General Installation troubleshooting

originContent: BPCells tries to print informative error messages during compilation to help diagnose the problem. For a more
translatedContent: BPCells tries to print informative error messages during compilation to help diagnose the problem. For a more

originContent: verbose set of information, run `Sys.setenv(BPCELLS_DEBUG_INSTALL="true")` prior to `remotes::install_github("bnprks/BPCells/r")`. If you still can't solve the issue with that additional information, feel free to file a Github issue, being
translatedContent: verbose set of information, run `Sys.setenv(BPCELLS_DEBUG_INSTALL="true")` prior to `remotes::install_github("bnprks/BPCells/r")`. If you still can't solve the issue with that additional information, feel free to file a Github issue, being

originContent: sure to use a [collapsible section](https://docs.github.com/en/get-started/writing-on-github/working-with-advanced-formatting/organizing-information-with-collapsed-sections) for the verbose installation log.
translatedContent: sure to use a [collapsible section](https://docs.github.com/en/get-started/writing-on-github/working-with-advanced-formatting/organizing-information-with-collapsed-sections) for the verbose installation log.

originContent: </details>
translatedContent: </details>

## Contributing

originContent: ## Contributing
translatedContent: BPCells is an open source project, and we welcome quality contributions. If you

originContent: BPCells is an open source project, and we welcome quality contributions. If you
translatedContent: are interested in contributing and have experience with C++, along with Python

originContent: are interested in contributing and have experience with C++, along with Python
translatedContent: or R, feel free to reach out with ideas you would like to implement yourself.

originContent: or R, feel free to reach out with ideas you would like to implement yourself.

originContent: We're happy to provide pointers for how to get started, time permitting.
